author: lightclient
content:
Future of EOA/AA Breakout #2 scheduled for May 7 @ 1400 UTC
https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1032

author: wjmelements
content: If it can be a smart contract, it need not be a precompile

author: rjected
content: by that logic we shouldn't have precompiles, they are valuable for a specific reason: precompiles are valuable in not wasting everyone's cycles and money doing things in-evm when we have native libs that are strictly better

author: lightclient
content: I don’t think it’s about saving people time. It’s that it’s infeasible to implement the precompile in EVM efficiently enough to be useful. If it were efficient, there shouldn’t be a precompile. Regardless of how much time or money the standard contract takes to develop

author: rjected
content: Yeah I didn't mean time to develop, more time in cpu

author: rjected
content: and money as in, because native is so much faster, the price to use the precompile can be much lower

author: rjected
content: basically assuming contract development is free, contracts are always secure, and contracts are developed instantly

author: chfast
content: That's the theory. In practice people copy C code to solidity and modify it until it compiles. And then they say the "EVM implementation" is not practical. And we agree.
